segment.source: Migration Store Types Overview (Windows 10)
segment.target: Migration Store Types Overview (Windows 10)

segment.source: Migration Store Types Overview
segment.target: Migration Store Types Overview

segment.source: Migration Store Types Overview
segment.target: Migration Store Types Overview

segment.source: When planning your migration, you should determine which migration store type best meets your needs.
segment.target: When planning your migration, you should determine which migration store type best meets your needs.

segment.source: As part of these considerations, determine how much space is required to run the User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 components on your source and destination computers.
segment.target: As part of these considerations, determine how much space is required to run the User State Migration Tool (USMT) 10.0 components on your source and destination computers.

segment.source: You should also determine the space needed to create and host the migration store, whether you are using a local share, network share, or storage device.
segment.target: You should also determine the space needed to create and host the migration store, whether you are using a local share, network share, or storage device.

segment.source: In This Topic
segment.target: In This Topic

segment.source: Migration Store Types
segment.target: Migration Store Types

segment.target: Local Store vs. Remote Store

segment.source: The /localonly Command-Line Option
segment.target: The /localonly Command-Line Option

segment.source: Migration Store Types
segment.target: Migration Store Types

segment.source: This section describes the three migration store types available in USMT.
segment.target: This section describes the three migration store types available in USMT.

segment.source: Uncompressed (UNC)
segment.target: Uncompressed (UNC)

segment.source: The uncompressed (UNC) migration store is an uncompressed directory with a mirror image of the folder hierarchy being migrated.
segment.target: The uncompressed (UNC) migration store is an uncompressed directory with a mirror image of the folder hierarchy being migrated.

segment.source: Each directory and file retains the same access permissions that it has on the local file system.
segment.target: Each directory and file retains the same access permissions that it has on the local file system.

segment.source: You can use Windows Explorer to view this migration store type.
segment.target: You can use Windows Explorer to view this migration store type.

segment.source: Settings are stored in a catalog file that also describes how to restore files on the destination computer.
segment.target: Settings are stored in a catalog file that also describes how to restore files on the destination computer.

segment.source: Compressed
segment.target: Compressed

segment.source: The compressed migration store is a single image file that contains all files being migrated and a catalog file.
segment.target: The compressed migration store is a single image file that contains all files being migrated and a catalog file.

segment.source: This image file is often encrypted and protected with a password, and cannot be navigated with Windows Explorer.
segment.target: This image file is often encrypted and protected with a password, and cannot be navigated with Windows Explorer.

segment.source: Hard-Link
segment.target: Hard-Link

segment.source: A hard-link migration store functions as a map that defines how a collection of bits on the hard disk are “wired” into the file system.
segment.target: A hard-link migration store functions as a map that defines how a collection of bits on the hard disk are “wired” into the file system.

segment.source: You use the new USMT hard-link migration store in the PC Refresh scenario only.
segment.target: You use the new USMT hard-link migration store in the PC Refresh scenario only.

segment.source: This is because the hard-link migration store is maintained on the local computer while the old operating system is removed and the new operating system is installed.
segment.target: This is because the hard-link migration store is maintained on the local computer while the old operating system is removed and the new operating system is installed.

segment.source: Using a hard-link migration store saves network bandwidth and minimizes the server use needed to accomplish the migration.
segment.target: Using a hard-link migration store saves network bandwidth and minimizes the server use needed to accomplish the migration.

segment.source: You use a command-line option,/hardlink , to create a hard-link migration store, which functions the same as an uncompressed migration store.
segment.target: You use a command-line option,/hardlink , to create a hard-link migration store, which functions the same as an uncompressed migration store.

segment.source: Files are not duplicated on the local computer when user state is captured, nor are they duplicated when user state is restored.
segment.target: Files are not duplicated on the local computer when user state is captured, nor are they duplicated when user state is restored.

segment.source: For more information, see Hard-Link Migration Store.
segment.target: For more information, see Hard-Link Migration Store.

segment.source: The following flowchart illustrates the procedural differences between a local migration store and a remote migration store.
segment.target: The following flowchart illustrates the procedural differences between a local migration store and a remote migration store.

segment.source: In this example, a hard-link migration store is used for the local store.
segment.target: In this example, a hard-link migration store is used for the local store.

segment.source: migration store comparison
segment.target: migration store comparison

segment.source: Local Store vs. Remote Store
segment.target: Local Store vs. Remote Store

segment.source: If you have enough space and you are migrating the user state back to the same computer, storing data on a local device is normally the best option to reduce server storage costs and network performance issues.
segment.target: If you have enough space and you are migrating the user state back to the same computer, storing data on a local device is normally the best option to reduce server storage costs and network performance issues.

segment.source: You can store the data locally either on a different partition or on a removable device such as a USB flash drive (UFD).
segment.target: You can store the data locally either on a different partition or on a removable device such as a USB flash drive (UFD).

segment.source: Also, depending on the imaging technology that you are using, you might be able to store the data on the partition that is being re-imaged, if the data will be protected from deletion during the process.
segment.target: Also, depending on the imaging technology that you are using, you might be able to store the data on the partition that is being re-imaged, if the data will be protected from deletion during the process.

segment.source: To increase performance, store the data on high-speed drives that use a high-speed network connection.
segment.target: To increase performance, store the data on high-speed drives that use a high-speed network connection.

segment.source: It is also good practice to ensure that the migration is the only task the server is performing.
segment.target: It is also good practice to ensure that the migration is the only task the server is performing.

segment.source: If there is not enough local disk space, or if you are moving the user state to another computer, then you must store the data remotely.
segment.target: If there is not enough local disk space, or if you are moving the user state to another computer, then you must store the data remotely.

segment.source: For example, you can store it in on a shared folder, on removable media such as a UFD drive, or you can store it directly on the destination computer.
segment.target: For example, you can store it in on a shared folder, on removable media such as a UFD drive, or you can store it directly on the destination computer.

segment.source: For example, create and share C:store on the destination computer.
segment.target: For example, create and share C:store on the destination computer.

segment.source: Then run the ScanState command on the source computer and save the files and settings to DestinationComputerNamestore.
segment.target: Then run the ScanState command on the source computer and save the files and settings to DestinationComputerNamestore.

segment.source: Then, run the LoadState command on the destination computer and specify C:Store as the store location.
segment.target: Then, run the LoadState command on the destination computer and specify C:Store as the store location.

segment.source: By doing this, you do not need to save the files to a server.
segment.target: By doing this, you do not need to save the files to a server.

segment.source: Important
segment.target: Important

segment.source: If possible, have users store their data within their %UserProfile%My Documents and %UserProfile%Application Data folders.
segment.target: If possible, have users store their data within their %UserProfile%My Documents and %UserProfile%Application Data folders.

segment.source: This will reduce the chance of USMT missing critical user data that is located in a directory that USMT is not configured to check.
segment.target: This will reduce the chance of USMT missing critical user data that is located in a directory that USMT is not configured to check.

segment.source: The /localonly Command-Line Option
segment.target: The /localonly Command-Line Option

segment.source: You should use this option to exclude the data from removable drives and network drives mapped on the source computer.
segment.target: You should use this option to exclude the data from removable drives and network drives mapped on the source computer.

segment.source: For more information about what is excluded when you specify /LocalOnly, see ScanState Syntax.
segment.target: For more information about what is excluded when you specify /LocalOnly, see ScanState Syntax.
